properties.Title: Update To Civil Emergency Alert Issued By Government Of Saskatchewan
properties.Summary:
Description: Update for the Civil Emergency Alert issued by the Government of Saskatchewan. The state of emergency in Saskatchewan remains in effect. UPDATE: Phase 3 of Re-Open Saskatchewan became effective June 8. Allowable maximum people for public and private gatherings has been increased to 15 inside and 30 outside. UPDATE: For Northwest Region. The public health order restricting travel for Northwest Region has been lifted, allowing for travel in and out of the northwest region and between communities. At this time and until further notice, the Northwest Region remains in Phase 2 of Re-Open Saskatchewan. During all Phases of Re-Open Saskatchewan all public health orders, which includes physical distancing by at least two metres from others, is to be followed and applied in all public and private gatherings.
Expires: 2020-06-22T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-06-15T16:36:32-06:00, 736C502D-AFC1-2137-8579-6AD63A7C9794
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential wintry weather over higher elevations of the Okanagan Connector overnight and early Tuesday morning. There exists the potential for wet snow to fall over the Okanagan Connector above 1600 metre elevation overnight and early Tuesday morning as a cold low moves inland and spreads precipitation over the southwest interior. Due to the nature of cold lows, precipitation will be scattered across the southwest interior. The exact accumulation will vary depending on the intensity of any one of those pockets of showers and the duration. Generally, no more than 4 cm is expected. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-16T15:06:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-15T23:07:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1986048082.2020
Area: Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of hot, humid weather ahead for southern Manitoba. Temperatures will soar for Tuesday and Wednesday across southern Manitoba. A warm front pushing into the region will bring a hot, humid air mass into the province. Temperatures will climb above 30°C both days, and humidex values will reach the mid- to upper-30s as the humidity increases. On Tuesday night, a breezy southerly wind combined with the hot and humid air mass will keep temperatures very warm through the night. In the Red River Valley, temperatures will likely only drop to around 23 or 24°C, while areas in southeastern Manitoba will see temperatures dip a couple degrees cooler. A cold front will move through the province on Wednesday night, bringing a return to more seasonal temperatures and humidity. In addition to the heat, much of southern Manitoba will see the potential for thunderstorm activity over the coming days. Some of these thunderstorms will likely be severe with a variety of threats. The humid conditions will support very heavy rainfall with some thunderstorms that develop. Areas in southeastern Manitoba affected by recent heavy rains may see more torrential rainfall; on Wednesday, the region could see narrow bands of training thunderstorms resulting in significant rainfall accumulation. Please refer to the daily local forecasts and ECCC's Thunderstorm Outlook product (disseminated on ECCC's weather-related social media accounts) for further details. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-16T12:29:18-00:00

properties.Title: Flood Warning Issued For The Rat River And Joubert Creek
properties.Summary:
Description: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a Flood Warning for all points along the Rat River and Joubert Creek due to high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca follow @MBGov and @MBGovRoads on Twitter or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2020-06-17T16:00:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-06-15T12:11:45-05:00, DED814BA-E6F0-8B85-0B93-BF2CB4F290A6
Area: All points on the Rat River and Joubert Creek
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Minimum temperatures: +1 to +5 (coolest in low lying areas). Locations: eastern mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton Island. Time span: early Tuesday morning. Remarks: Patchy frost is expected to form as clear skies and light winds coincide with cool temperatures, especially in low lying areas. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-16T12:34:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-15T23:50:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0740020719.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. The ground, already near saturation, has little ability to absorb further rainfall. A low pressure system over northern Alberta will continue to give rain at times heavy to the Fort Nelson and Muncho Lake - Stone Mountain Park regions tonight. Since Sunday morning, 30 to 70 mm of rain has fallen across the region from this storm. An additional 10 to 15 mm is forecast for tonight. Rain showers will continue on Tuesday. Given the wet antecedent conditions in the region this past month (including a similar weather system last weekend), the ground is already saturated in many areas. The prolonged moderate to heavy rainfall may result in higher overland runoff. Flood warnings and advisories from the BC River Forecast Centre can be found at: http://bcrfc.env.gov.bc.ca/warnings/index.htm . ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-16T15:04:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-15T23:05:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2964771140.2020
Area: Muncho Lake Park - Stone Mountain Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures reaching 29 degrees Celsius combined with overnight lows near 18 degrees Celsius are expected for the next 2 days. Temperatures reaching 29 to 30 degrees Celsius with humidex in the mid to high thirties combined with overnight lows near 18 degrees Celsius are expected for tomorrow and Wednesday. A cooler airmass will arrive on Thursday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-16T21:34:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-16T05:35:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3328198248.2020
Area: Pikangikum - Poplar Hill - MacDowell, Pickle Lake - Cat Lake, Fort Hope - Lansdowne House - Ogoki
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of rain, at times heavy, continues. The ground, already near saturation, has little ability to absorb further rainfall. A low pressure system over northern Alberta will continue to give rain at times heavy to the northern BC Peace region tonight. Communities in the north Peace have recorded 30 to 90 mm of rain so far from this storm; the highest amounts have been observed near the Rockies over communities like Hudson Hope. A further rainfall of 10 mm is forecast for tonight before the rain ends. Given the wet antecedent conditions in the region this past month (including a similar weather system last weekend), the ground is already saturated in many areas. The prolonged moderate to heavy rainfall may result in higher overland runoff. Flood warnings and advisories from the BC River Forecast Centre can be found at: http://bcrfc.env.gov.bc.ca/warnings/index.htm . ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-16T14:36:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-15T23:00:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3884192404.2020
Area: B.C. North Peace River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Minimum temperatures: near plus 1. Locations: in low lying inland areas of central, western, and southwestern Newfoundland. Time span: late overnight and early Tuesday morning. Remarks: Patchy frost is expected to form as clear skies and light winds coincide with cool temperatures, especially in low lying areas. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
